segments.text: You all ready?
Yes.
And start, if you'll start with your name and the date you were born and where you were born.
I am Florencio Gutierrez.
I was born in Guerrero, Tamaulipas, Mexico in February 4th, 1899.
Guerrero lies two miles south of
the old Zapata City, 60 miles south of Laredo.
The history begins in 1910 when General Porfirio Diaz was president of Mexico.
The history of the revolution begins then.
At which time he had completed about 30 years of government.
In 1910, Mexico celebrated the centenary.
And soon afterward, a man named Francisco Madero from Parra, Coahuila, started a movement to change the government in Mexico.
After a
Well, there was a period of time when Díaz was fighting back, wasn't there?
Francisco Madero started the political movement, and he was arrested by the
Porfirio Diaz government was released, and then he started the actual revolution in the state of Chihuahua.
After some time, his forces took over the city of Ciudad Juarez across from El Paso, Texas.
After that event, General Porfirio Diaz
resigned from his presidency and moved to Paris, France.
After the elections were held, Francisco Madero was elected president and took office about 1912.
In February 1913,
He was assassinated.
He and the Vice President.
Pino Suarez.
The Vice President Pino Suarez.
And the former Secretary of War, Victoriano Huerta, took over the government.
Now, how did it happen that your family left Mexico?
What time was it during the revolution that your family left?
Do you want me to follow that Mexico City events?
Why don't you go ahead and tell me when your family left Guerrero?
In April 1913,
Due to the threat of the revolutionaries, we left Guerrero in April 1913 and crossed into Zapata, Texas.
Did you all come together?
The family, just my mother and five children.
My father had gone at night with my uncle.
Well, why did your father have to leave at night?

On account of the threat of the Revolutionary War threatening to take the town and assassinate my uncle, Sinecio Gutierrez, who was then the president in the city, which is like the mayor here in the United States.
So we moved to Zapata in April, and then in August we moved to Nuevo Laredo, Mexico.
and then we could enter the school.
Then on December 1st, we moved to Laredo, Texas, and have been living here since.
Why did you move from Nueva Laredo to Laredo?
On account of the threat of the revolution too, that they were threatening to take over, the Carranza forces were threatening to take the town.
Of Nuevo Laredo?
Of Nuevo Laredo.
Uh-huh.
And your father, had he been for the Huerta government?
No, no.
He was a civilian.
He was just a civilian.
My uncle was the politician.
Your uncle.
Well, whose side was he on?
With the Porfirio Díaz, and then the Madero government, and then the Huerta government, they tried to follow the line.
But these were the legitimate federal governments.
Because he was the president, he tried to follow the existing government.
And that meant that the people who were against Huerta were after your uncle.
Were after my uncle.
Right.
Then from there, when we moved to Laredo, Texas, that was in December 1913.
Then on the last day of December of 1913, the Carranza forces attacked the city of Nuevo Laredo.
After three days of fighting, the revolutionary forces withdrew.
And then on April 14, 1914, the Huerta forces, military forces, burned the...
government buildings, including the Kostrop's house, bought it and left the town.
Then a few days afterward, the Carranza forces took over the town.
And then... Well, during that period, what was one of the first things you did in Laredo?
Did you go right to school in Laredo?
When we came to Laredo in January 1914, I went to a private school to learn English.
How many years had you been to school in Mexico?
Up to and including fifth grade.
Fifth grade.
That's where I learned the basic subjects.
Then from the private school,
I changed to the public school and then stayed through the fifth grade and quit to get to work.
You did?
Yeah, get to work.
Life was hard at the time.
So you went through fifth grade in Mexico and then you went through fifth grade in the United States.
Well how, what sort of work did you do?
I used to work with one of these money exchange offices that were very popular.
I was the cashier and the janitor and earning two dollars a week.
How old were you then?
Very happy because I had a job to do.
Life, everything was cheap at that time, including meat was 9 cents a pound.
Oh, how wonderful.
Flour was 3 cents a pound.
A loaf of bread, 5 cents.
A suit of cloth, 12, 15 dollars.
A pair of shoes, 2 or 3 dollars.
Life was very simple then.
There were no automobiles, just a few automobiles at that time, 1914.
You want me to mention about the exodus of people?
Yes.
When we were in Nuevo Laredo,

Every time there was a threat that the revolutionary forces would come to Nuevo Laredo, people would move to the American side, with all their meager belongings, and without any hindrance from the American authorities.
They had free movement, back and forth.
And things settled down, they moved back to Nuevo Laredo.
But we made only one movement in December and stayed here.
Why did your family stay here?
Do you know?
Let me tell you a story.
When we came to Laredo, we moved to that tenement house.
We arrived at about noon.
That's where I saw that loaf of bread.
It was a tenement house and a loaf of bread in a garbage can.
At a tenement house?
Tenement house.
My goodness.
It's owned by Dr. Saffirini in downtown.
Do you know Laredo?
Not that well.
The rent was $7.80 a month.
We worked here about a three or four room house.
and they had a gas stove with two burners and an oven.

Well, mother prepared supper, we had supper, we were five children, and my father, after we had supper, my mother told me years later, she said, when we had supper, I told Juvenal, who was my father, she said, Juvenal, I don't know what your plans are,
But I'm not going back to Mexico with all these conveniences.
I'm not going back to Mexico.
We used to cover this mesquite charcoal
Chips and petroleum stoves.
So she says, I'm not going back to Mexico.
This is the first guy's stove she'd ever cooked up.
With all these conveniences.
Very happy to have that convenience.
Well, what was your family life like in Guerrero before the revolution?
What did your father do?
Well, she had a butcher shop first.
And then he had a saloon.
But it was not quite like these saloons.
No, it was a place of reunion for the medium class people.
in Guerrero.
Sort of a place for the men to get together.
It was a respectful place.
Like in many small towns in Mexico.
They had a billiard, and then a little gambling just to entertain themselves.
There was nothing else to do in Guerrero.
And your father's name now was?
Juvenal.
Juvenal Gutierrez.
How long had he lived in Querétaro?
My ancestors came from the city of Querétaro many, many years ago.
One of my ancestors, an uncle, was General Bernardo Gutiérrez de Lara.
He was governor of Tamaulipas during the independence.
He went to Washington on horseback to get aid.
But he said that the price that they asked was too high and told him, thanks, no.
And then came back.
And then when the movement of independence ended in 1925, Agustín de Turbide became emperor.
And then after a year or so, people were discontent.
They wanted a republic.
So they exiled him.
And then in his absence, Mexico enacted a law that if he ever came to Mexico, that he would be executed.
But he didn't know anything about it.
After two or three years, he came from Spain and landed in a place between Matamoros and Tampico.
My uncle Bernardo Gutierrez was gone.
He captured that man and executed him right away.
He was the one that actually executed him?
My uncle.
And then afterward, after he had landed, Mexico issued a decree to spare his life and to send him to Mexico City.
Said that it was too late, that he was
Six feet from the ground.
Oh, I had never heard that he was later spared.
He was already dead.
That's too bad.
That was one uncle.
Another uncle was a priest.
He surveyed lots of lands here in these counties, and they still respect his surveys.
Oh, during this time, of course, all this part of Texas.
That was in 1910, 160 years ago.
1810, during the War of Independence.
Right, and that's when all this part of the country was still part of Mexico.
Yes, and we came from another man.
Our great-grandfather was Antonio.
And he settled down in Monterrey and then in Guerrero.
That's where we come from.
My grandfather's name was Florencio Gutierrez.
Awesome.
How come so many people moved to Guerrero?
Guerrero, in about 1900, the Mexican government issued a decree, designated a, what do you call it,
section around the, all along the American border as a free, free, what do you call it?
Free trade.
Free trade.
And all those people prospered.
Guerrero was a prosperous town.
They had trade with Nuevo Laredo, with Hebronville, with Corpus, with Matamoros, and the Rio Grande was navigable at that time.
And the people that
from Guerrero that lived in the little ranch towns came to Guerrero to have their babies born there.
Because of the better medical facilities?
Facilities and then their loyalty to Mexicans.
They want to... Oh, you mean people from the United States would go to Guerrero?
Yes, but the Mexican people.
People who were on this side of the Rio Grande would go there so their babies would be born in Mexico.
Because they...
lived part of the time in Herrera and then had ranches here.
And that was the custom there.
This was back before the revolution.
Oh, it was in 1890.
And then Mexico found out that it was just encouraging smuggling because all the stores along the water were filled up with American merchandise and it was easy to smuggle them into Mexico.
So they, what do you call it, they canceled that.
that law, and they can never renew it again.
Well then, what did that do to Guerrero?
It started to decay.
It started to decay, and this was before the revolution?
About 1900.
About 1900, and so after that there was a decline.
It started to decay, and when we left it had a population of about 4,000.
And how many had it been?
How many people had lived there, say, in 1900?
The thing is, it was not so many people.
The trade, it was a trade center, trade center, to bring the merchandise, and from there, they smuggled it into the terrain, and now in the interior of Mexico.
At that time, the smugglers used to cut their trade by horseback.
And then at that time, the coin was all silver pesos.
They carried it with them.
But the trade was carried in silver coins.
What was the housing like then when you were growing up?
The housing?
Yeah.
Houses were built to last forever.
It took about two or three years to build a house out of rock.
About three feet wide, the walls.
And then the ceilings were about three or four feet deep.
And they used them as fortresses to arrest the Indians.
Was there trouble with Indians all along?
Yes, at that time, sure.
They had trouble with Indians back in 1900.
So those houses were built forever.
And your family house that you grew up in, was it one of these stone houses?
All the houses were made of rock.
All the houses.
Of course, the old guerrillas'
destroyed now, decayed.
What happened to it?
Well, when they built the dam, it flooded the town, half of the town, and it was abandoned and built a new town, new Guerrero, just across from Falcón.
But all Guerrero's gone.
Well, it's gone and very few people live there.
But life was very, it was very quiet and people like commune.
very simple very simple in those days and then the revolution came i don't have any idea what would have happened to me there cannot be in the revolution i could be there a patriarch with about
12 children and 40 grandchildren with a long beard.
You might be.
Did your family own land?
Did your father have land?
No.
He didn't have any land?
No, just our house.
So he was really more of a merchant than a farmer.
A merchant.
Well, was he able to get out of Mexico with anything when he fled to Zapata?
That was only because we had on, because we moved in the horse carriage.
That was my mother and five children.
So you weren't able to take anything with you?
Everything was left.
How did you get across the river?
It was a total loss for us, like a millionaire that has a half a million council lost.
We are just as bad, just as bad off as we were because he lost everything and we lost everything.
We moved by carriage to Zapata, to the river.
There was one of those chalans, they call it, ferry boats, but flat.
They moved in with those big sticks that the gondoliers used.
They moved to the American side.
The same thing on the American side.
Well, how come you went to Zapata?
Because it was the closest place.
It was the closest.
Did you have any family in Zapata?
I bought a man named Spone, who was the political chief in Zapata.
He had a store, and he very graciously gave us the house to live there.
He sold the house and he moved to the store.
And he just gave it to you?
That was the kind of man that he was.
My goodness.
I'll never forget that man.
He was a merchant, because he was an acquaintance of my papa and my uncle.
And he told me, you move to our house, and we stay there one week, and then move to the ranch.
What was the name of the ranch you moved to?
San Bartolo.
It was one mile or two miles off the river.
We used to walk from the ranch to Zapata once a week to buy groceries.
Walk, just walk.
What did your father do during this period to make a living?
At that time there was a business of money exchange.
He exchanged Mexican money to American back and forth.
In Zapata?
No, right here in Laredo.
No, in Zapata we did nothing.
He did nothing.
And then when you got to Nueva Laredo, was he exchanging money then?
We were exchanging money.
Well, so your father had had some education too.
Well, yes.
Normal education.
Normal education.
What would a normal education be in Mexico in his generation?
How many years of school do you think?
Six or seven years.
Six or seven.
Very few people went to college.
And see, during the...
people would go to France for their education.
There's much French influence in Mexico.
They prefer the French schools.
So only the very rich could afford to send their children to France.
That was that resentment in Mexico always.
And it was fake to us in school, in the tests and everything.
That resentment against the United States.
Against the United States?
Sure, because of the territory that they took.
I can never forget that.
That's during the Mexican War in 1845.
In 1836, when they took Texas first.
First, right.
Three years later, the other part of... All the rest of it, all the way to California.
But there's one fact.
When the Spaniards came to Mexico, Mexico was just a piece of land
from Mexico City to Veracruz and Tampico.
That was Mexico.
And the Spanish came here and took over all this land up to San Francisco.
So, in fact, Mexico didn't have anything.
They didn't lose anything.
When Mexico won the war, Spain just left all this by default, left all these lands, and Mexico took it.
But in fact, they were not Mexican lines, they were Spanish, Spanish lines.
So that's two sides to every question.
But you did grow up with the idea that the United States was sort of, well, how would you describe it?
Well-grounded, land-grounded.
Land-grounded.
Well, how did you feel then when you actually moved to the United States?
Did that bother you?
Different opinion.
We saw the peaceful, the freedom that we have here, and then the facilities for education.
We changed the picture.
Like my mother said, I don't want to go back to Israel.
But now, how many children were there in you?
You said there were five children.
Five born in Guerrero, five born here.
Five more born here.
And two children that died in infancy.
There were ten in the family.
Who was the oldest?
I was the oldest.
You were the oldest.
Ten years old when you left Mexico.
I was nineteen, thirteen, fourteen years old.
Fourteen years old.
And then...
My father died in 1927, and then my mother died 40 years later, in 1967.
She was about 89 years old, in good health, but she was very methodical in her life, in her diet and everything, very methodical.
Well, you said when you got here, you went then through some more schooling.
You went to private school.
Private school first to learn English.
How did your family afford to send you to private school?
Because it cost $2 or $3 a month.
Oh, it wasn't expensive.
And I walked from my house to the school.
It was five blocks from there.
That was Instituto Dominguez.
They have the other business now.
And then from there I moved to central school.
When you came by Matamoros, you see a big school there.
It was newly built when I moved.
When I went there, I stayed there one year and a half.
And then after the fifth day, I quit to help the family expenses.
And you went to work exchanging money.
Exchanging money.
Well, when did you meet your wife?
Exchanging money and janitor too.
Everything.
And cleaning hospitals and everything.
How long did you work at that job?
About a few years and then, you see, at that time there was a big market for
Mexican silver coins in New York.
And these agents would buy it and ship it to New York.
I used to do that work, count that money, pack it, seal it, and then take it to the space to ship it to Zimmermann and Fossey, what the company did.
broke many years ago.
And then I took those bags of money, eight or ten bags of money, every evening to the bank for safekeeping until the next day.
And then one day the cashier of the bank told me, I want you to come and work with us.
I told him, but I don't work with Mr. Cardenas.
No, he said, I talked to him.
He said, you can work with us.
After you get through with us, you can go and work with him.
And that's the arrangement we made.
I started to work for $35 a month.
And what year was that?
Well, that was a pretty good salary in 1918, wasn't it?
$35 a month.
And then when they started the draft here, I raised it and it was placed in fifth class, which was clerical work.
At that time it was very important, clerical work.
So in November the work ended and I didn't sell it.
And then in the next war, in 1941, I was 42 years old.
I was married, I had four children.
So I was placed in another fifth class or something.
I never had to serve.
But my boys, one of them, he was serving the reserve.
And then the little one, the engineer, entered the Air Force in Lackland.
But he broke a knee or something, and they told him, if we operate, we can keep to here.
By that time, he had his degree in engineering.
And we can keep, if you don't want, we'll have to discharge it.
Said, give me the discharge.
And then the other one, Carlos, was married with three children, so they didn't touch him.
They didn't touch him.
You've been lucky about that.
Yes.
Well, when did you meet your wife?
You said you wouldn't have met your wife if it hadn't been for the revolution.
Because we met here.
They had a kindergarten.
And my little sister was a student there.
I started to see her.
And then one Labor Day, back in 1933, we went to Monterey, my sister, herself, to Monterey.
I had a little...
Chevrolet car at that time, new car.
We spent two or three days there.
And when we came back, we became engaged.
And in November, we got married.
I thought we had a very good life.
How did it happen that your wife had come to Laredo?
You see, they were the Carranza people.
So long as the revolution was going on, they were doing all right.
That's her family.
They were pro-Carranza.
Because his father was with the Carranza administration.
He was a collector of... What do you call this?
State collector of taxes.
No, federal collector of taxes in Monterrey.
And what was his name?
You see, you cut me there.
Oh, what was his last name?
His last name.
Garza.
Garza.
Garza.
Then when Carranza was killed, he died.
He had a heart attack in Monterrey.
So the family moved to Nuevo Laredo and opened a kindergarten.
This was in Nuevo Laredo.
Nuevo Laredo, kindergarten.
Then from Nuevo Laredo, they moved to Laredo, Texas, and got the kindergarten downtown.
Then they, you see I just, through my sister, I got to see them.
There were five sisters and she was the prettiest one.
But you don't think they would ever have moved to Nuevo Loreto if it hadn't been for the revolution?
No, their father had lived.
It was one of those circumstances.
Just a matter of chance.
Like I say.
We lost everything in the revolution, but I gave my wife.
And all three children, she raised them like gentlemen.
Very obedient.
They called us on telephone quite often, and we go and visit them.
We have a good life.
We have good daughters-in-law.
You see, making allowances for everything.
We have good relations.
So your oldest son, let's see, what does he do now?
He's with the Massachusetts Insurance Company in Houston.
And his name is?
Massachusetts is Florencio Gutierrez Jr.
In the last four years, he has sold more than $1 million in insurance.
My goodness.
This was the president's club.
Every year they send him to...
Springfield, Massachusetts to take courses.
And then every year they have a convention in San Francisco, Puerto Rico, and he takes his wife with him to have a week of fun.
Oh, how wonderful.
And he was an Aggie.
He was A&M.
He was about three years studying petroleum engineering.
But he could not make it.
He said, Father, I cannot make it.
I'm going to quit.
And then he moved to Houston.
But he's a born, born safe man.
He has been doing very well.
And then your second son is Carlos.
Carlos.
He...
went to the University of Houston.
He first went to East Texas, I don't know.
What's the name, Conroe or East Texas?
It's Nacogdoches, I think.
No, that's another town.
Comer's.
Comer's.
Comer's.
And then he went to the University of Texas.
And then, while he was in high school, he knew this country.
My wife's sister married Mr. Adolf Kahn, who used to be the assistant customs collector here in Laredo.
And then Mr. Kahn, his first wife died and left him two boys and one girl.
And then he married my wife's sister.
And they have a boy and a girl.
And then through that relationship we know the Luisa's parents.
We got together during forest and everything and that's how they met.
And then they got married when he was 20 years old.
Fortunately, we had fathers on both sides.
We had to tie them up.
Finally, they are on their own now.
And what does he do now?
He's with the shipping agents there called Le Parc Blanc Company.
They are shipping brokers.
And he's the second man in the office.
the owner and himself, and then personal 14 or 15 employees.
And then your youngest son is?
That's engineer, civil engineer.
He started with the highway department.
And then after four years, he got his license to be on his own.
And then in Houston, he has a big part of the expressway that he designed in Houston.
And then he left the highway department to be and went into partnership with a surveyor.
They stayed to work two or three years.
And then he did very well and they dissolved the partnership.
And then went to work with the Dow Company.
And then for a year or so and then he quit and now he joined another partner.
of architects.
And now he's doing very well.
What is his name?
Alberto.
Alberto David Gutierrez.
They are living now in Memorial Park.
You know, in Houston.
Yes, yes.
That's a very nice section.
They're renting a house.
They have a house and they sold it.
Now they want to buy another one, but it costs too much.
The more you wait, the more it will cost you.
That's true.
Well, your brothers and sisters, did they all stay in the United States too?
Yes, everyone.
One brother, he moved to Mexico City with my boss, a man named Francisco Cárdenas.
Mr. Cárdenas was from Nuevo León, and he became governor of Nuevo León.
First he was a senator in the Congress, and then my brother moved with him just to help him and everything.
and then he became governor of Malayalam.
And then he died in Mexico, married there, and died in Mexico City.
So there was one that went... All the rest of them lived here in the States.
Was he one of the ones that had been born in Mexico?
Yes.
He was the second in the family.
So he went back, but everybody else stayed.
Well, do you ever go back to Mexico?
Do you go to Mexico to visit much?
Do you go to Mexico to visit?
Yes, quite often, every year.
To Mexico City several times.
in conventions, bank conventions, and custom brokers conventions.
We have been to different towns, to Guanajuato, Acapulco, Mazatlan, Mexico City, Guadalajara.
We have visited all those places during the conventions.
But we like it to go just for pleasure, not to live.
Well, why wouldn't you want to live there?
Because we are used to this kind of life, quiet life.
all the freedom that we want, the freedom of expression, and then the security in our own lives.
And then the sanitation.
You go to Mexico City, you can get sick by drinking a glass of water or a salad or something.
But do you feel like the revolution was a good thing in the long run for Mexico?
It was justified.
It cost too much in lives and property
but it had to come.
Like I said, General Porfirio Díaz maintained the country in peace, but the country could not develop because the main resources were in the hands of a few hands, his own general.
Then the railroads and the mines were owned by the British and the oil companies.
American companies owned the oil companies too, and then the
The transportation was owned by Canadians and irrigation systems by Canadians and British.
So all the main industries, basic industries, were owned by foreigners.
So it was kept in the, what do you call it, in the undeveloped state.
They wanted to get the riches, the profits from Mexico.
So just ordinary people didn't have a chance.
That's what I say.
Not to get the opportunity for jobs.
When Mexico expropriated the oil companies, they demanded indemnity.
But in justice, the companies ought to have paid Mexico instead of getting... Why?
Because during the revolution of Carranza, the American companies engaged a man, Mexican general.
I don't remember what was his name.
They recruited about two or three thousand men, well equipped, well armed and everything, to protect the oil companies.
And that happened for about five or six years during the revolution.
And that was during the World War.
So they took all the oil from Mexico.
Mexico never got a cent of revenue for that, for all those years.
They just kept that money in power until things became stabilized.
So injustice was a good move.
The oil companies had to carry a better attitude or something.
They never spent a cent for building schools, hospitals, or anything.
And then the executives lived like kings, segregated from the rest of the people.
So those conditions cannot last in any question.
So one thing brought the other thing.
And you feel like Lázaro Cárdenas was really justified in the expropriation.
And he should not have paid them anything.
Well, you've talked about some of these men.
You were telling me that Villa wasn't, that he was sort of a bandit.
What do you feel about Villa?
That's what I say.
Pancho Villa.
You know, just a bandit.
The revolution came, it was an opportunity for them to...
to wage vengeance on the other people.
He kept that fellow Luis Terrazas, that millionaire, with him always.
And he blackmailed him, took all that he could with him.
Finally he released him.
But he was just a bandit like anybody else.
And then they remember when Pancho Villa attacked Columbus.
back in 1916, out of revenge for, it's said that the United States, President Wilson called, double-crossed him.
As a result of that, Mexico and the United States had a treaty that in case of an invasion from bandits, each country had the right to
invade the other country to, in hot, for Saudi people, but with a troop, troops not to exceed 500 men.
So, American people sent Pershing with 500 men, but before you know, they had two or three thousand soldiers already.
And Pancho Villa used to be in the mountains watching, watching them, looking for him.
And then they went so deep in looking for him, they went to, to
the state of Durango.
Finally they had a clash with the Mexican troops.
Then finally they recalled Pershing to make him commander of the expeditionary forces in Europe.
And finally the United States withdrew the troops and Pancho Villa never was caught.
Now, how did you learn so much about Mexican history?
Because I was always interested.
I read papers, magazines, and everything.
So you just sort of kept up with it?
I kept up with it.
I like to keep pace with history, and then the European history, too.
I remember it was in August 1914 when they killed that, what was the Russian general?
Austrian.
in Sarajevo that started the revolution.
Of course, that was a pretext.
The war had to come anyway.
It was going to come because of Germany's ambition.
You see, the ambition of Vienna was to have a line of communication through Constantinople.
They wanted to build a railroad.
There was the alliance between Germany
Italy and Austria on one side, and then England, France and Russia on the other side.
And then when the war came, then the United States just dashed his ambition to dominate the world, and again in 1941.
And during that period, during World War I, though, there were a lot of German agents in Mexico, you were telling me.
That's what I mean, because of the resentment.
So they allowed them to operate in Mexico.
You see, they had some sort of, when the ships left the port, they would sink them with U.S. U-boats, as they called them.
So it was a thorn on the side for the United States.
And during this period, of course, you were here in Laredo.
One thing I didn't find out, did you actually see any battles?
Did you actually see any battles when you were growing up?
Well, in Laredo, we would just watch the shooting and everything, and the soldiers would go to houses and see them moving around.
when they attacked Nuevo Lareo, but Nuevo Lareo was very well fortified.
They never got too close to the... Of course at that time the revolutionaries didn't have any guns, just rifles.
And this, the government troops, they had cannon, cavalry, infantry.
So they could not take it.
They killed about 3,000 Carrasistas and they burned them there in the big fire.
Now it was very, very painful for Mexico to have this revolution.
And economically it has grown.
Politically it came back to the old regime.
Oh, really?
Same thing.
political party that nominates all the candidates.
They call the other opposition party.
But it's only pretence to pretend that there is democracy.
Politically the same thing, but economically it has grown.
What do you think the reason for the economic growth is?
Well, the position that it has in Mexico-Casa, the natural resources, then the people that are being educated.
They've got a good practice building red road bridges.
They've got so many.
They're experts at that.
This bridge over here, the one on the Mexicans, the new bridge was built by Mexicans, designed and built by Mexicans, the pedestrian bridge.
So they are well experienced in that.
Have you traveled on the Pacific from El Paso to Mazatlán?
No, I haven't done that yet.
They have a beautiful railroad there built by Mexicans too.
So many tunnels and then canyons, big canyons.
It's a civic route from Chihuahua to Mochis.
We traveled that once.
It's a beautiful city.
All built by these Indians, what do you call them?
Tarahumara Indians.
Do you think the Indians are getting more educated?
